INQUIRY COMMISSION'S REPORT ON MR ONG ENG GUAN'S
ALLEGATIONS
(Motion of condemnation)


    Order read for resumption of adjourned debate on question [1st March, 1961],

    "That this Assembly takes note of the Report of the Inquiry Commission into certain allegations made by Mr Ong Eng Guan in the Legislative Assembly on the 10th and 12th December, 1960, as contained in Paper Cmd. 7 of 1961, and condemns Mr Ong Eng Guan for his dishonourable conduct unbecoming of an elected representative of the people in that he repeatedly used his privilege in this Assembly as a cloak for spreading malicious falsehoods to unjustly injure innocent persons both inside and outside this Assembly."-(The Deputy Prime Minister).

    Question again proposed.

2.33 p.m.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the findings of Mr Justice Chua in the Commission of Inquiry into the allegations made by Ong Eng Guan in this Assembly against the Prime Minister and the Minister for Labour and Law in December 1960 show conclusively that Ong Eng Guan is an inveterate liar.

    During the one year that Ong Eng Guan served as a Minister in our Government, his low intrigues and cult of individualism as against collective leadership and responsibility resulted in his expulsion from the People's Action Party and the Government Bench. Even as a Member of the Opposition, Ong Eng Guan had a role to play, but again within short space of five months, he revealed his true nature of unprincipled and irresponsible conduct unbecoming of an elected representative of the people of Singapore by persisting in spreading malicious falsehoods, knowing them to be false.

Column: 1120



    It has been alleged by Ong Eng Guan and his cronies that his freedom of speech had been curtailed even before his expulsion from the People's statement of fact and it is important to refer to page 5, paragraph 13 of the Report of the Chua Commission of Inquiry which states:

    `Mr Ong Eng Guan stated that whatever he had to say had been said in his examination-in-chief. Towards the end of his evidence, Mr Ong Eng Guan, in answer to my questions, expressed himself satisfied that he had been given every opportunity to say what he wanted to say and to call all relevant witnesses, and that there had been no attempt to silence him in this Commission.'

And what was the end result? The last two sentences of paragraph 14 of the Report are clear:

    `Mr Ong Eng Guan, however, had nothing to disclose. He did not even have any facts on which he based his allegations.'

    It should be noted too, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the subject of inquiry under the Commission were the same three allegations which Ong Eng Guan said he would substantiate in this House on 23rd December, 1960, but he decided to run away by resigning his seat in this Assembly on 29th December, 1960. Instead of substantiating his three allegations in the Commission of Inquiry, Ong Eng Guan offered the childish explanation that his solicitors had advised him that he had not made any allegations at all but only merely making an inquiry. As is well known, ignorance is no excuse in the eyes of the law and Ong Eng Guan is not an illiterate man. He is a graduate of Melbourne University and a practising accountant. However, even assuming the fact that Ong Eng Guan and his solicitors did not know the meaning of the word "allegation", then what did Ong Eng Guan mean when he said these brave but foolish words in Hansard, Volume 14, No. 10, dated 23rd December, 1960, at column 871:

    `Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to substantiate all the things I have said.'

The substantiation never came, neither in this Assembly when he chose the coward's way of running away by resigning, nor in the Commission of Inquiry. To have failed in substantiating his three allegations was bad enough, but in the

Column: 1121

Commission of Inquiry, Ong Eng Guan made further allegations against the Prime Minister. See the first sentence of paragraph 11 of the Report:

    `Mr Ong Eng Guan in the course of his examination-in-chief made further allegations against the Prime Minister.'

These were just as reckless and groundless. I shall only refer to one - unfortunately in which I am indirectly affected - in which he claimed, with regard to the question of my nomination, or rather the rumour that I had resigned from my insurance company to become a candidate for the P.A.P., which was untrue at that time, that he then got the Party's Chairman (Dr Toh Chin Chye), now the Deputy Prime Minister, to see the Secretary-General and that the question was resolved with the Secretary-General of the P.A.P. threatening to resign unless certain people were nominated. But when Ong Eng Guan was asked whether the Deputy Prime Minister and Chairman of the People's Action Party was to be called as a witness to this so-called episode, Ong Eng Guan saw no point in doing so, and it was left to the Commissioner to call Dr Toh Chin Chye; and it has been proved that Dr Toh's evidence did not support the story of Ong Eng Guan. I quote paragraph 11 of the Report, 7th line from the bottom of page 4:

    `Dr Toh Chin Chye further said that Mr Lee Kuan Yew never mentioned that he would resign or threatened to resign from the Party or its leadership if Mr Yong Nyuk Lin was not nominated. I accept the evidence given by Dr Toh Chin Chye. In fact, Dr Toh Chin Chye's evidence was not challenged by Mr Ong Eng Guan.'

This proves that he who lies must have more lies to support his case and all that is needed is to disprove one lie and the full pack of lies crumble down.

    The Opposition has tried to allege that the People's Action Party won the 1959 general elections because of Ong Eng Guan. This is not true. It was the P.A.P. which built up Ong Eng Guan. It was the good work of the Party and its 13 City Councillors which delivered the goods. Of course, Ong Eng Guan wants to take the credit for everything. Unfortunately, Ong Eng Guan was an ambitious and a power-crazed man, and that

Column: 1122

proved his undoing and he won the disrespect of his colleagues. He is a mentally sick man who would lie in order to gain a point. He speaks on the spur of the moment and, being an opportunist and without principles, has degenerated into becoming a habitual liar.

    Yesterday, the Member for Aljunied mentioned that his colleague would stand for the Hong Lim, by-election. It is quite clear, Sir, that the attitude in which the Member for Aljunied spoke was like a master and servant attitude. Perhaps, since Ong Eng Guan is no longer a Member of this House, it would have been more appropriate if the Member for Aljunied had used the terminology not of his "colleague" but his "master".

    We all know that at election time all sorts of charlatans, cranks and quacks also present themselves as candidates before the voters. Only unprincipled politicians think they can fool the people. There is a saying that you can fool some of the people part of the time, but you cannot fool all the people all the time. Let us therefore not under-rate the intelligence and the commonsense of the electorate and that they are unable to distinguish between right from wrong, truth from lies and integrity from corruption. In the long run, truth will always prevail.

    This Report is clear and concise. Ong Eng Guan is to be emphatically condemned by this House for his dishonourable conduct in being a purveyor of malicious falsehoods and bringing the dignity of this House into disrepute.

    The motion of the Deputy Prime Minister is to be supported in no uncertain terms and Members of the Opposition who choose either to abstain or to reject the motion plainly show where they stand - that is, they stand for untruths and lies.

2.45 p.m.

    Mr John Mammen (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion moved by the Deputy Prime Minister. Sir, before I go into the findings of the Commission, may I touch on the statements made by the Member for Aljunied?

Column: 1123



    What he said yesterday, was that he disagreed with and rejected the Commission's findings. But on what grounds has he or his colleagues got to disagree with and reject the findings of the Commission's Report? If he and his colleagues have any reasonable grounds whatsoever to disagree with the findings of the Commission, then they should have come out with reasons, so that at least the people of Singapore or in the near future the electorate of Hong Lim will know why the Member for Aljunied and his colleagues disagreed with the Commission's findings. But the Member for Aljunied preferred not to come out with any reasons whatsoever to say that he and his colleagues disagreed with the Report. Instead he made an announcement that Mr Ong Eng Guan will be contesting the by-election in Hong Lim. But we the P.A.P., since the formation of the P.A.P., have met these challenges. This sort of challenge is not new to the P.A.P. In 1957 the P.A.P. met the challenge in a by-election on a constitutional issue. The P.A.P. Secretary-General accepted that challenge. But what happened? The person who challenged absconded. He never faced the P.A.P. in that by-election. In 1958, it was the Kallang by-election. Even though much had been said about the P.A.P. City Councillors and the P.A.P. Mayor and what they did in the City Council since 1957, all the Right-wing groups in Singapore ganged up together to smash the P.A.P. in the Kallang by-election. But the P.A.P., with determination and mass support, faced it. What was the result? The P.A.P. won. That in itself shows that the P.A.P. can still face any sort of challenge from Left-wing opportunists or the Right-wing reactionary groups of political parties in Singapore.

    I rise to inform my friend the hon. Member for Aljunied, to make sure that on Nomination Day his colleague will not betray him but will be in Hong Lim to submit his Nomination paper. Before he made the announcement, he should have made it clear that his master or his colleague, Mr O.E.G., will be there on Nomination Day to sign his paper. The man who brought up the P.A.P., as the

Column: 1124

Opposition has said; Mr Ong Eng Guan brought up the P.A.P.? Nonsense! The P.A.P. brought Ong Eng Guan up. And since the P.A.P. brought him up to this position, and he could betray the Party, then my advice to my friend, the hon. Member for Aljunied, is to see that Ong Eng Guan will not betray him even on Nomination Day.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I now come to the lengthy speech of the hon. Member for Cairnhill. In this Assembly, the Member for Cairnhill has often given the impression that if there is no Lim Yew Hock Government, then there will be no internal self-government in Singapore. I will say this: if there is no P.A.P., if there is no mass support for the P.A.P., and if there is no trade union backing for the P.A.P., then I should say that the past Lim Yew Hock Government was even prepared to work under the Rendel Constitution as stooges of the colonial government. Because the P.A.P. put up a strong fight, and the masses were behind the P.A.P., that is why the Lim Yew Hock Government had to go to the United Kingdom for a new constitution. That was no credit for the S.P.A. or the Labour Front, because the P.A.P. agitated for it, and the people of Singapore know that the P.A.P. took the risk courageously, and the S.P.A. or the Labour Front would not risk it. They know it, and the British Government knows it too well, that the only Party with mass backing, the only Party with full mass support, is the P.A.P.; and they have no other alternative, but to agree to a new constitution.

    The second point, Mr Speaker, Sir. The Member for Cairnhill was saying yesterday that he started his political career in 1948. He started from Keppel, shifted to Havelock, and then to Cairnhill. Now I say, he started from the Western Ocean, now he is going to land in the Eastern sea, and that would be his end! He toppled over the vessel's side and started from the sea! So he shifted and shifted his way and is going to the Eastern sea! I hope that will be his end, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, everybody is looking anxiously at the forthcoming by-election and its issue. But we, the P.A.P., are prepared and ready to face

Column: 1125

the electorate of Hong Lim. But one thing - and the P.A.P. would like to make this clear - even though the Opposition have made it clear that they are not in any way connected with Mr Ong Eng Guan, still the line they are taking now and Ong Eng Guan's line are the same. A party which, up to 1960, was saying that Singapore could get independence only through merger. But in 1961 they suddenly changed and they say Singapore must have complete independence of its own and we must fight the colonial government. Eng Guan's line is the same. It was the P.A.P.'s stand from the beginning after 1957, when the Constitution was agreed upon, that the P.A.P. would like to have independence after merger with the Federation of Malaya. And today, the Right-wing party which opposes a Left-wing government fighting against colonialism comes out openly and says, "The P.A.P. is a stooge of the colonial government. The P.A.P. does not like independence." I think that is exactly the same line as Eng Guan took in the Assembly. That is why I say, even though they declare in the Assembly that they are in no way connected with Eng Guan, but in underground they are backing Ong Eng Guan for their self-interest. And in the Hong Lim by-election, we will have to expose these Right-wing politicians and the Left-wing opportunists.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there is a smear going around that the trade union movement is no longer supporting the P.A.P. nor are they going to support the by-election. This is another trick just to split the P.A.P. and the trade union movement. But we are sure that in this issue which is immediately facing the Party, the Government and the country as a whole, the trade union movement will go all-out in force to see that the people of Singapore, especially the electorate of Hong Lim, support the P.A.P. stand on this issue.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, if Mr Ong Eng Guan suddenly changes his mind on Nomination Day and decides not to contest in Hong Lim, then I hope his colleague, the Member for Aljunied, will be there at least to see the P.A.P. candidate there.

Column: 1126



2.56 p.m.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, Members will recollect the extraordinary conduct of the Member for Cairnhill when he rose to speak on the motion yesterday afternoon. The Member for Cairnhill worked himself up to a frenzy and spoke with great vehemence, quite naturally drawing return fire from the Government Benches. On several occasions during these exchanges, you, Mr Speaker, had to intervene in the interest of order.

    I was at first puzzled at the strange conduct of the Member for Cairnhill. So after his speech, I met the Prime Minister in the C.P.A. Room and asked him, "Why was Lim Yew Hock raving like a madman?" The Prime Minister replied, "Don't take him seriously. He was merely play-acting." Now, I want to explain to the House the reasons which, to my mind, led the Member for Cairnhill into this exhibition of play-acting.

    I have no doubt that the leader of the S.P.A., the Member for Cairnhill, has suddenly discovered that he had led the S.P.A. into an ambush. The S.P.A. wanted to destroy the P.A.P. at all costs, and, being the Opposition Party, it was within their right to try to achieve this object. They thought they found in Ong Eng Guan a useful instrument for discrediting the P.A.P. So when Ong Eng Guan made his reckless allegations, the S.P.A. calculated that even if a large number of these allegations were discounted, there must be a residue of half-truths still there. Ong Eng Guan, as a former member of the Party who held high posts in the past, according to the Opposition, was in possession of damaging Party and Government secrets. So therefore it was in their interest, or so they thought, to encourage Ong Eng Guan to press on. That was the reason for giving Ong Eng Guan not only their secret support but open encouragement. When Ong Eng Guan resigned his seat in this Assembly, there was a risk that he might scuttle not only from this Assembly but from the by-election as well. So while the S.P.A. announced in advance that they would not contest the Hong Lim by-election,

Column: 1127

they hoped to have other conditions obtaining -that some people could be deluded into voting for this P.A.P. renegade. But to their discomfiture, they discovered that the Commission of Inquiry cleared the P.A.P. Ministers concerned of any vestige of suspicion. Furthermore, the Commission found Ong Eng Guan to be a liar, a perjurer and a bigamist. The S.P.A., therefore, suddenly found themselves in a position of open support for a perjurer and a bigamist. They had walked straight into a trap of their own making. There was no escape. The Member for Cairnhill, therefore, decided to hit out all-round so that, in the frenzy of his words, people would lose sight of the predicament in which he had placed himself and his party. That is why we had the extraordinary spectacle of the Member for Cairnhill yesterday fulminating and gesticulating.

    Sir, in the course of his speech, he made a number of allegations which can hardly be expected to go unchallenged. I will deal with some of them, and no doubt my colleagues will dispose of the rest. Some of these charges have no direct bearing on the motion. But nevertheless, as these issues have been raised, you will no doubt permit me to reply to them. I myself am directly concerned with one of the wild swipes which the Member for Cairnhill let fly. He says that I, as Minister for Finance, went to London begging for money. Sir, that is a gross and malicious distortion of the truth. Everybody is fully aware of the reasons for the London talks held between the Singapore and British Governments last August. We told the British Government that since defence was their constitutional responsibility, it was their duty to make adequate contribution to the upkeep of our local defence forces. If no adequate contribution was forthcoming, then we would be prepared to abolish the defence forces. And indeed a number of ancillary services have been so disbanded. But the British Government agreed to make financial contribution for the maintenance of some of the

Column: 1128

more essential units. But by no stretch of the imagination can our request that the British Government should meet its moral obligations in respect of defence be considered as begging.

    Then there was the contribution for the expansion of the airport facilities. The authority to license routes of airlines making use of the Singapore Airport vests in the British Government and not in the Singapore Government. As such, it was only right and proper that the British Government made an adequate contribution for the expansion of the airport services. Nothing could be more foolish than to suggest that this stand of the Singapore Government amounts to begging.

    The third item was over Exchequer loans. Here again we were not asking for free money. These loans are to be made on normal terms governing British Exchequer loans, which are made between one Government and another. These loans have to be repaid, and the borrower has to pay interest at the current market rate. Loan negotiations between Governments are a normal part of the financial activity of any government. All governments, even the wealthiest, have at one time or another occasion to resort to borrowing from other governments. When the Member for Cairnhill calls it begging, obviously this is a case of sour grapes, for when his Party formed the Government they were unaware of the external financial resources which were available to Singapore to finance its development programme.

    Another comment of the Member for Cairnhill which deserves special attention is this. He deplored the proceedings of the Commission of Inquiry because it had led to what he termed "character assassination". Now what does this so-called "character assassination" consist of? It is no more than that the Commission found that Ong Eng Guan was legally married to another woman when he took his second wife to Hong Kong to be married. Now who is to blame for raising this bigamy issue in the proceedings of the Commission?

Column: 1129

May I - read an extract from paragraph 12 of the Report? The Commissioner says:

    `Although the Prime Minister did not bring this question of multiplicity of wives in this Commission, Mr Ong Eng Guan insisted (his counsel supporting him) that he should be allowed to clear his name. I, very reluctantly, allowed him to do so lest it be said that I wanted to silence him.'

I was present during this part of the proceedings of the Commission. According to my recollection, the Commissioner on no less than three occasions refused to allow this issue to be brought up. But finally he was prevailed upon by Ong Eng Guan and his counsel. That, of course, took the lid off, and Ong Eng Guan had only himself to blame for widening the scope of the Inquiry to cover his own private life. There was no character assassination; first, because Ong Eng Guan has no character to be assassinated; he was simply a liar and a scoundrel. Secondly, assassination means the murder by one party of another. In the proceedings of the Commission, what took place cannot be described as assassination. It was a simple case of suicide. Ong Eng Guan himself brought up the subject, and he has to take the consequences of his own stupidity.

    Another foolish accusation levelled by the Member for Cairnhill was that my colleague, the Minister for Culture, had fired the first shot in the Hong Lim by-election. He regarded the speech of the Minister for Culture as a piece of electioneering. I myself consider the clear and dispassionate analysis of the Minister for Culture to be an attempt to bring together the complicated threads of this episode to show a pattern of underlying political forces attempting to make use of Ong Eng Guan to advance their own interests. This was a piece of political analysis, not political electioneering. But I cannot say the same for the speech of the Member for Cairnhill. He was electioneering, nakedly and unashamedly. Let me recall some of the statements made by him.

    He stated - echoing Mr Ong Eng Guan - that it was Ong Eng Guan who, as Mayor of Singapore, created the mass support which carried the P.A.P. into

Column: 1130

power at the last general elections. The S.P.A. and other Right-wing opportunists can never, or will never, see that the P.A.P. has built up its mass support on the basis of its own programme and its consistent and determined fight against all forms of oppression. But to ascribe the success of the P.A.P. to other forces is an old game played by bankrupt political forces on the Right. Before Ong Eng Guan was ever heard of, the Labour Front, the Liberal Socialists and the Democratic Party - ancestors of the S.P.A. - had in the past vehemently and consistently stated that the mass support which the P.A.P. enjoyed was engineered by the under-cover Communist organisation. Now, if that was so, when the former Labour Front broke up the Communist under-cover organisation, why did the P.A.P. not collapse? If their analysis was correct, then this was the inevitable consequence. But far from collapsing as a result of the 1956/57 purges, the P.A.P. went on from strength to strength. The reasons for the mass support enjoyed by our Party are clearly stated in an article in the Sixth Anniversary Souvenir number of the Party. This is being serialised in the Sunday Mail - and I can only ask Members who seek enlightenment to follow the series with care and attention.

    To come back to my main argument. The Member for Cairnhill now tries to place the credit for the mass support of the P.A.P. on Ong Eng Guan. If this is not open electioneering by the S.P.A. on behalf of Ong Eng Guan in the Hong Lim by-election, then I do not know what it is. But the statement of the Member for Cairnhill is utterly foolish. When will he understand that a political movement does not depend on individual heroes? The P.A.P. has repeatedly stated that there is no room in the movement for heroic individualism which, far from doing the Party any good, does it considerable harm. If Ong Eng Guan was responsible for the mass support of the Party, then his expulsion from the Party would have seen the withdrawal of this mass support. Only wishful thinkers would believe that this has happened.

Column: 1131

Anybody present at the Lumumba protest meeting last Sunday could easily have assessed the degree of mass support enjoyed by the P.A.P.

    The Member for Cairnhill referred to this meeting. He said that the large attendance at this meeting was entirely due to what he termed "Left-wing adventurers" - a phrase borrowed from current P.A.P. terminology. By this term, he could either mean the under-cover Communist organisation, or the more militant trade unions. I will not attempt to divine his thoughts. But if he had been present, he would have seen that the stadium was packed to capacity long before the organised arrival of the trade union members. They marched in at about 10.30 a.m. onwards, and only a part of the procession organised by these unions could find space in the stadium.

    May I now turn to the principal issue? It is the contention of my colleague, the Minister for Culture, that in the Hong Lim by-election there is a ganging-up against the P.A.P. This ganging-up is between Ong Eng Guan, a political opportunist without any principle whatsoever but pretending to have Left-wing and anti-colonial principles on the one hand, and on the other hand a group of Right-wing opportunists who had been by-passed by the tide of events. These are the S.P.A. representing pro-colonial Right-wing forces and political mountebanks such as David Marshall and Mrs Leon-Soh. All these groups are smarting under defeats repeatedly administered to them in the past by the P.A.P. They are hoping to experience sweet revenge by manipulating Ong Eng Guan. I do not think this move on their part is at all clever. But they have decided upon this crazy adventure without knowing its full and ghastly implications which only now are unfolding themselves.

    The S.P.A. disclaim any support of Ong Eng Guan now that the man has been thoroughly exposed. But they say one thing - their actions point to the opposite direction. They now say, when they are cornered, that they do not support Ong Eng Guan. The same way

Column: 1132

when Ong Eng Guan was cornered in the Commission, he said that he had not made any allegations against the Prime Minister and the Minister for Labour and Law. But this is merely playing with words. We judge a man not merely by his words but by his deeds. If the S.P.A. and other sinister Right-wing forces want to give their support to Ong Eng Guan, so be it. We will take them on in Hong Lim and give them the thrashing of their lives. This is not the first time there has been a ganging-up against the P.A.P. Members will recollect the Kallang by-election when there was another big ganging-up. But the collection of disreputable political forces is no guarantee of victory.

    May I now pose the issue contained in the Deputy Prime Minister's motion clearly and briefly? We are here to condemn a man who, in effect, had been found by a judicial tribunal to be a liar, a perjurer and a bigamist. The issue is basically a moral one. This Assembly must voice its moral indignation the dishonourable conduct of one of its former Members. It is no use trying to put up pretexts for evading the issue - pretexts which are too flimsy to deceive a child. If the man has been guilty of dishonourable conduct, then it is the duty of this Assembly to condemn him, so that in future rogues and scoundrels will be dissuaded from besmirching the dignity and reputation of the Assembly. I repeat - this is our moral duty and I look forward with interest to listening to what the Member for Tanglin has to say, for he professes to be a very strong upholder of moral principles and a disciple of moral rearmament. Let there be no evasion or side-trackings, and let no one be influenced by political expediency into abstention from voting on this issue. That is the way of a coward.

3.20 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture (Mr Lee Khoon Choy): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Aljunied appeared to be picking up the tactics of Mr Ong Eng Guan yesterday. He rejected the Chua Report as being outside the terms of reference, and
